Craps Game Pseudocode

December 6, 2023
Anonymous
Write pseudocode for playing the game of craps
ChatGPT

Certainly! The game of Craps involves rolling two six-sided dice and betting on the outcome of the roll. Here's a simple pseudocode representation of a basic Craps game:

plaintext
function playCraps():
    displayWelcomeMessage()

    while true:
        // Player places a bet
        betAmount = getBetAmount()

        // Roll the dice
        roll = rollDice()

        // Check the outcome of the roll
        if isComeOutRoll(roll):
            handleComeOutRoll(roll)
        else:
            handlePointRoll(roll)

        // Display current status and ask if the player wants to continue
        displayCurrentStatus()
        if not playAgain():
            break

    displayGoodbyeMessage()

function rollDice():
    die1 = random(1, 6)
    die2 = random(1, 6)
    total = die1 + die2
    return total

function isComeOutRoll(roll):
    // A come-out roll is the first roll in a new round
    return roll in [2, 3, 7, 11, 12]

function handleComeOutRoll(roll):
    if roll in [7, 11]:
        playerWins()
    elif roll in [2, 3, 12]:
        playerLoses()
    else:
        // Set the point for subsequent rolls
        point = roll
        displayPointMessage(point)
        handlePointRoll(point)

function handlePointRoll(point):
    while true:
        // Roll the dice again
        roll = rollDice()

        // Check if the roll matches the point, player wins
        if roll == point:
            playerWins()
            break
        // Check if the roll is 7, player loses
        else if roll == 7:
            playerLoses()
            break

function playerWins():
    // Handle the player winning scenario
    displayWinMessage()
    increasePlayerBalance()

function playerLoses():
    // Handle the player losing scenario
    displayLoseMessage()
    decreasePlayerBalance()

function displayWelcomeMessage():
    // Display a welcome message to the player

function displayPointMessage(point):
    // Display the point for the current round

function displayWinMessage():
    // Display a message indicating the player has won

function displayLoseMessage():
    // Display a message indicating the player has lost

function displayCurrentStatus():
    // Display the current status of the game, including player balance, etc.

function playAgain():
    // Ask the player if they want to play again
    // Return True if the player wants to play again, False otherwise

function displayGoodbyeMessage():
    // Display a goodbye message to the player

Please note that this pseudocode is a simplified representation, and you may need to adapt and expand it based on your specific requirements or game features.

Assume the players are not betting and rewrite the pseudocode
ChatGPT

Certainly! If players are not betting, we can simplify the pseudocode for a basic Craps game. Here's a version where players are just rolling the dice and the game continues until the player decides to exit:

plaintext
function playCraps():
    displayWelcomeMessage()

    while true:
        // Roll the dice
        roll = rollDice()

        // Check the outcome of the roll
        if isComeOutRoll(roll):
            handleComeOutRoll(roll)
        else:
            handlePointRoll(roll)

        // Display current status and ask if the player wants to continue
        displayCurrentStatus()
        if not playAgain():
            break

    displayGoodbyeMessage()

function rollDice():
    die1 = random(1, 6)
    die2 = random(1, 6)
    total = die1 + die2
    return total

function isComeOutRoll(roll):
    // A come-out roll is the first roll in a new round
    return roll in [2, 3, 7, 11, 12]

function handleComeOutRoll(roll):
    if roll in [7, 11]:
        playerWins()
    elif roll in [2, 3, 12]:
        playerLoses()
    else:
        // Set the point for subsequent rolls
        point = roll
        displayPointMessage(point)
        handlePointRoll(point)

function handlePointRoll(point):
    while true:
        // Roll the dice again
        roll = rollDice()

        // Check if the roll matches the point, player wins
        if roll == point:
            playerWins()
            break
        // Check if the roll is 7, player loses
        else if roll == 7:
            playerLoses()
            break

function playerWins():
    // Handle the player winning scenario
    displayWinMessage()

function playerLoses():
    // Handle the player losing scenario
    displayLoseMessage()

function displayWelcomeMessage():
    // Display a welcome message to the player

function displayPointMessage(point):
    // Display the point for the current round

function displayWinMessage():
    // Display a message indicating the player has won

function displayLoseMessage():
    // Display a message indicating the player has lost

function displayCurrentStatus():
    // Display the current status of the game

function playAgain():
    // Ask the player if they want to play again
    // Return True if the player wants to play again, False otherwise

function displayGoodbyeMessage():
    // Display a goodbye message to the player

This version removes the betting-related components, as the players are simply rolling the dice without placing bets.

ChatGPT

Certainly, here's the simplified pseudocode without the welcome and goodbye messages:

plaintext
function playCraps():
    while true:
        // Roll the dice
        roll = rollDice()

        // Check the outcome of the roll
        if isComeOutRoll(roll):
            handleComeOutRoll(roll)
        else:
            handlePointRoll(roll)

        // Display current status and ask if the player wants to continue
        displayCurrentStatus()
        if not playAgain():
            break

function rollDice():
    die1 = random(1, 6)
    die2 = random(1, 6)
    total = die1 + die2
    return total

function isComeOutRoll(roll):
    return roll in [2, 3, 7, 11, 12]

function handleComeOutRoll(roll):
    if roll in [7, 11]:
        playerWins()
    elif roll in [2, 3, 12]:
        playerLoses()
    else:
        point = roll
        displayPointMessage(point)
        handlePointRoll(point)

function handlePointRoll(point):
    while true:
        roll = rollDice()

        if roll == point:
            playerWins()
            break
        elif roll == 7:
            playerLoses()
            break

    displayWinMessage()

    displayLoseMessage()

    // Display the point for the current round

This version focuses solely on the game mechanics without including welcome or goodbye messages.

Anonymous
Please adapt this code to track game results for a statistical simulation
ChatGPT

Certainly! To adapt the code to track game results for a statistical simulation, we can introduce variables to count the number of wins and losses. Here's an example of how you could modify the pseudocode:

plaintext
function playCrapsSimulation(numSimulations):
    totalWins = 0
    totalLosses = 0

    for _ in range(numSimulations):
        // Roll the dice
        roll = rollDice()

        // Check the outcome of the roll
        if isComeOutRoll(roll):
            result = handleComeOutRoll(roll)
        else:
            result = handlePointRoll(roll)

        // Update total wins and losses
        if result == "win":
            totalWins += 1
        elif result == "lose":
            totalLosses += 1

    displaySimulationResults(totalWins, totalLosses)

function handleComeOutRoll(roll):
    if roll in [7, 11]:
        return "win"
    elif roll in [2, 3, 12]:
        return "lose"
    else:
        point = roll
        handlePointRoll(point)
        return "continue"

function handlePointRoll(point):
    while true:
        roll = rollDice()

        if roll == point:
            return "win"
        elif roll == 7:
            return "lose"

function displaySimulationResults(totalWins, totalLosses):
    // Display the results of the simulation
    // You can also calculate and display win percentage, average rolls per game, etc.

function rollDice():
    die1 = random(1, 6)
    die2 = random(1, 6)
    total = die1 + die2
    return total

function isComeOutRoll(roll):
    return roll in [2, 3, 7, 11, 12]

In this adaptation, the playCrapsSimulation function now takes a parameter numSimulations, indicating how many simulations you want to run. The results of each simulation (win or lose) are tracked, and at the end of the simulation, the displaySimulationResults function is called to show the overall results.

You can customize the displaySimulationResults function to display the statistics you're interested in, such as win percentage, average rolls per game, etc.

Anonymous
please write this pseudocode as if using R with tidyverse
ChatGPT

Certainly! If you were to implement a simulation of the Craps game in R with the tidyverse, you might structure the code as follows:

R
library(tidyverse)

# Function to simulate a single game of Craps
simulate_craps_game <- function() {
  roll <- sum(sample(1:6, 2, replace = TRUE))

  if (is_come_out_roll(roll)) {
    return handle_come_out_roll(roll)
  } else {
    return handle_point_roll(roll)
  }
}

# Function to check if it's a come-out roll
is_come_out_roll <- function(roll) {
  roll %in% c(2, 3, 7, 11, 12)
}

# Function to handle the come-out roll
handle_come_out_roll <- function(roll) {
  if (roll %in% c(7, 11)) {
    return "win"
  } else if (roll %in% c(2, 3, 12)) {
    return "lose"
  } else {
    return "continue"
  }
}

# Function to handle the point roll
handle_point_roll <- function(point) {
  while (TRUE) {
    roll <- sum(sample(1:6, 2, replace = TRUE))
    
    if (roll == point) {
      return "win"
    } else if (roll == 7) {
      return "lose"
    }
  }
}

# Function to run a simulation with a specified number of games
run_craps_simulation <- function(num_simulations) {
  results <- replicate(num_simulations, simulate_craps_game())
  
  # Display simulation results or perform further analysis
  total_wins <- sum(results == "win")
  total_losses <- sum(results == "lose")
  
  cat("Total Wins:", total_wins, "\n")
  cat("Total Losses:", total_losses, "\n")
  cat("Win Percentage:", total_wins / num_simulations * 100, "%\n")
}

# Run the simulation with 1000 games
run_craps_simulation(1000)

In this code, functions are defined to simulate a single game of Craps (simulate_craps_game), check if it's a come-out roll (is_come_out_roll), handle the come-out roll (handle_come_out_roll), and handle the point roll (handle_point_roll). The run_craps_simulation function is then used to run a specified number of simulations and display the results using the tidyverse functions in R.
